revision.text:
{{Infobox comic strip |title=You Can with Beakman and Jax |image=[[File:YouCanWithBeakman&Jax,Logo.jpg|250px]] |caption=Title logo of comic, with Beakman (left), Jax (right), their U-can, and rainbow star. |creator= [[Jok Church]] |url= http://www.beakman.com |current= |status=Ended |syndicate=[[Universal Press Syndicate]] |genre=Science, education |first=July 14, 1991<ref name="E&D">{{cite news|url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/Article/Chat-and-Anniversary-for-You-Can-With-Beakman-and-Jax-Cartoonist|title=Chat and Anniversary for 'You Can With Beakman and Jax' Cartoonist |first=E&P|last=Staff|work=[[Editor & Publisher]]|publisher=Editor And Publisher.com|date=2006-06-20}}</ref><ref name="BrnLW">{{cite news|url=http://trademarks.breanlaw.com/74318575-u-can-with-beakman.html | title = CAN WITH BEAKMAN trademark | publisher = BreanLaw, LLC |date=1992-09-29}}</ref> |last=July 17, 2016<ref name="GoComics">{{cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/beakman/2016/07/17 |title=You Can with Beakman and Jax |publisher=GoComics |accessdate=2016-07-24}}</ref> }}
'''''You Can with Beakman and Jax''''', also known in its [[Spanish language|Spanish-language]] version as "El Mundo de Beakman" ("The World of Beakman"),<ref name=Uclick>{{cite web|url=http://www.universaluclick.com/text_features/beakmanespanol/| title=Features: El Mundo de Beakman by Jok Church| publisher=[[Universal Uclick]]| accessdate = October 6, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/| title=Google Translate| publisher=[[Google]]| accessdate = October 6, 2013}}</ref> is an American science and education [[Print syndication|syndicated]] [[comic strip]] by [[Jok Church]], which began on July 14, 1991.<ref name="E&D"/> The educational comicstrip, and planned television series, were originally intended to be a part of the ''[[Star Wars]]'' franchise, with real world facts about science, and languages.<ref name="AMU">{{Cite_web |url=http://www.cincypost.com/living/1998/beak030298.html |title=AMU Speakers Bureau - Jok Church |accessdate=2017-02-27 |publisher=Universal Press Syndicate |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040906044215/http://www.cincypost.com/living/1998/beak030298.html |archivedate=2004-09-06 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
The comic strip is a [[Text comics|text-based comic]], that answers readers' questions, with illustrations of the main characters, various objects, and, or the experiments being discussed. It is run as a single panel comic that appears in newspapers as a color, or black and white Sunday feature, in either a 1/4 page strip, or 1/2 tab format.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://images.amuniversal.com/ups/sales/UPS_Factsheet6_06.pdf|title=Universal Press Syndicate: Fact Sheet, June 2006 |publisher=[[Universal Press Syndicate]]|pages=2, 3|date=June 2006}}</ref> The comic has reached a readership of 52 million readers, in 13 countries.<ref name=SFBay/> About 80 percent of the letters it receives are from females.<ref name=SFBay/> From its comic origins, its lead character Beakman would later star in his own [[live action]] [[television series]], ''[[Beakman's World]]''.<ref name="Post2006">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2006/06/20/DI2006062000567.html|title=Comics: Meet the Artist|first=Suzanne |last=Tobin|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=2006-06-30}}</ref> The comic also branched out into other media, gaining numerous awards along the way. The comic continued for several months after its author died of a heart attack on April 29, 2016.<ref name=obit>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Jok-Church-Beakman-and-Jax-cartoon-strip-for-7396400.php|title=Jok Church, of Beakman and Jax cartoon strip for kids, dies at 67|author=Steve Rubenstein|date=5 May 2016|work=SFGate|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref> Jok's final remaining comic was published on July 17, 2016, just three days after its 25th anniversary of publication.<ref name=GoComics/>
==Format== [[File:Beakman,Strip,TabFormats.png|thumb|left|250px|Example of comic's, strip and tab formats. A = logo, B = question, C = text, D = inverted text, red boxes indicate background illustrations.]] The comic strip was originally named ''You Can with Beakman'' (also called ''U Can with Beakman''.<ref name="BrnLW"/> Its only main character at the time was '''Beakman Place''', a male figure with spiky blue hair, glasses, a neck tie, and a breast pocket full of instruments. Beakman is a non-[[scientist]] that learns about the world through books, and then finds ways to prove what he's read about.<ref name=ADE>{{cite news |url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn86033360/1994-05-10/ed-1/seq-10/png/ |title=National News: Cartoonist defends 'explosive' comic strip experiment|work=Adirondack Daily Enterprise|publisher=Northern New York Library Network Newspaper.com |date=1994-05-10 |page=10}}</ref> He was named after [[Beekman Place]], a small street on the east side of Manhattan, New York City.<ref>{{cite news |title= The Real Breakman, by Brenden Shea|work=Odyssey. March 2000, Vol. 9 Issue 3, page 45|publisher=[[Odyssey (children's magazine)]] |date=March 2000|page=C4}}</ref> The comic is in a question-and-answer format, in which a reader asks a question, addressed to either Beakman, or also later, his sister '''Jax Place''',<ref name="Post2006"/><ref name=Amzn>{{Cite book|isbn=0836270215|title=Beakman and Jax's Microscope Book: Product description|publisher=Amazon.com|date=December 2005}}</ref> a red head, with her hair curled up behind her head in blue circular bands, she wears glasses, and [[Knucklebones|jacks]] in her hair, and as [[earring]]s. Church provides the answer,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amuniversal.com/ups/speakers/church/ |title=Jok Church: INTERNATIONALLY SYNDICATED SCIENCE NERD |publisher=Universal Press Syndicate |accessdate=2013-10-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051024023930/http://www.amuniversal.com/ups/speakers/church/ |archivedate=October 24, 2005 }}</ref> usually by means of a simple experiment the children reading can do (often with parental assistance or supervision). A paragraph after the results of the experiment, in inverted text at the bottom of the comic, would explain the answer.
==Concept== The idea for doing a comic strip came to Jok while he was working for [[Lucasfilm]], and answering questions from [[George Lucas]]' [[fan mail]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cincypost.com/living/1998/beak030298.html|title=Beakman's World: Museum hosts hands-on show|first=Connie|last=Yeager|work=[[The Cincinnati Post]]|publisher=[[E. W. Scripps Company]]|date=1998-03-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040906044215/http://www.cincypost.com/living/1998/beak030298.html|archivedate=2004-09-06}}</ref> stating that he was “overcome by the bravery children showed by asking Mr. Lucas anything at all" and he "decided to write about real questions from real kids".<ref name=SFBay>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/?sec=article&article_id=8445 |title=Introducing Jok Church’s Comic - You Can with Beakman & Jax|first=Tom W.|last=Kelly|work=[[San Francisco Bay Times]]|publisher=sfbaytimes.com|archivedate=2008-10-11 |deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011132457/http://www.sfbaytimes.com/?sec=article&article_id=8445}}</ref> While working at [[Lucasfilm]], Jok began working on a project called "Here's How" a comicstrip and educational television series featuring [[C-3PO]] teaching foreign language and [[R2-D2]] explaining the more physical world", the idea was eventually shelved, but the concept later evolved into Jok's Comicstrip featuring a character named Beakman.<ref name="AMU"/> He would receive these science questions from children, and he would choose to answer them based on subjects that he didn't know about, and wanted to learn.<ref name="Post2006"/> The comic was written for an audience that includes children, but not exclusively children.<ref name="Post2006"/> He felt his purpose in making the comics was "to make sure my readers are not intimidated by the world through which they walk".<ref name=SFBay/> He would then research the subject, write, draw, and color the comics by using a Macintosh computer.<ref name=UCan1>{{cite book | last = Church | first = Jok | title = You Can with Beakman: Science Stuff You Can Do | publisher = Andrews McMeel Publishing | year = 1992 | page = 4 | isbn = 0836270045}}</ref> This process gained him criticism in May 1994 when he explained how to do an experiment separating [[hydrogen]] and [[oxygen]] from water, through [[electrolysis]] using a single jar, and a [[nine-volt battery]], for which he defended the comic strip, by explaining the small amount of gas that would be produced in this way would not be overly dangerous. This was reported to be the first time an experiment's safety was questioned.<ref name=ADE/>
Besides answering questions from children, Jok also took questions from adults. One such question came from the Canadian Prime Minister, [[Jean Chrétien]], who asked about why golf balls had little dents. Jok later explained that he "has world leaders periodically contribute to his ... feature."<ref>{{cite news |title=Syndicates/News Services: Prime minister asks.|work=Editor & Publisher |volume= 127 |issue=40|publisher=[[Editor & Publisher]] |date=1994-10-01}}</ref> Within the comic strip Jok also introduced an annual "Beakman and Jax Make Up Your Own Rules Contest", in which the reader could report on an experiment or research they did. There were up to 100 winners from around the world, and the prizes were such things as a free telescopes<ref>{{cite news |title=Life: Your Family, Melissa Baird|work=Marysville/Yuba City's Appeal-Democrat November 12, 1995, page C4|publisher=[[Appeal-Democrat]] |date=1995-10-12 |page=C4}}</ref> and copies of the Beakman & Jax books.<ref>{{cite news |title=Briefs: Cedar Rapids, Student wins book|work=The Cedar Rapids Gazette: Thursday, Nov. 10,1994, Page 3Y|publisher=[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)]] |date=1994-11-10 |page=3Y}}</ref>
==History and media== The comic first appeared in the [[Marin Independent Journal]], and was offered to them for free.<ref name=SFBay/> The earlier comic strips were then reprinted in three "Science Stuff You Can Do"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://openlibrary.org/search?q=Science+Stuff+You+Can+Do |title=Science Stuff You Can Do, Search on Open Library.org |publisher=Open Library|date=2013-10-12}}</ref> books, a ''Best of'', and was the bases for two specialty books, ''Beakman & Jax's Bubble Book'' and ''Beakman & Jax's Microscope Book''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://openlibrary.org/works/OL2697013W/The_Best_of_You_Can_With_Beakman_and_Jax |title=The Best of You Can With Beakman and Jax, on Open Library.org |publisher=Open Library|date=2013-10-12}}</ref> Shortly after the release of the first book June 1, 1992,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiebound.org/book/9780836270044 |title=You Can with Beakman: Science Stuff You Can Do, publication information. |publisher=[[American Booksellers Association]] |date=2013-10-12}}</ref> on September 18, 1992<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1095600/ |title=Beakman's World: Season 1, Episode 1, episode information. |publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] |date=2013-10-12}}</ref> an Emmy Award winning television series named [[Beakman's World]] began, starring [[Paul Zaloom]] as the show's main character, along with three female lab assistants over the years, Lester the Rat,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.commonsensemedia.org/tv-reviews/beakmans-world |title=Beakman's World - Television Review |publisher=[[Common Sense Media]] |date=2013-10-12}}</ref> and two puppet penguins.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ba-da-boom, ba-da-bing, ba-da-'Beakman'|last=Staff|work=Bedford Gazette|publisher=Bedford Gazette|date=1993-10-03}}</ref> According to Jok the television series was "written to build a bridge between children and the adult members of their family," and "we created the show to be like a live action cartoon."<ref name="Post2006"/> Beakman's sister '''Jax''' however, was not included in the television series, which Jok referred to as "my one disappointment with the show."<ref name="Post2006"/> Although his sister wasn't present in the television show, two of Beakman's other relatives did appear on the television show, his mother '''Beakmom''',<ref>{{cite news |first=Aryeh Dean|last=Cohen|date=2003-10-03|title=The Logi-cal choice for concerned parents|newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|page=18}}</ref> and his brother '''Meekman'''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tv.com/shows/beakmans-world/sound-barrier-beak-mania-and-healthy-living-988550/recap/|title=Beakman's World, Season 4 Episode 19, Recap. "Sound Barrier, Beak-mania and Healthy Living" |newspaper=[[TV.com]]|date=1995-02-02}}</ref>
In 1995 an official website opened for the strip published by the "North Bay Network", it won many awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://webapp1.dlib.indiana.edu/virtual_disk_library/index.cgi/4273355/FID3542/res/encat/102981.htm |title=You can with Beakman and Jax |publisher=[[Indiana University]].com|date=2013-10-12}}</ref> It later moved to its current location in 1996, published by [[Network Solutions]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whoismind.com/whois/beakman.com.html |title=Beakman.com - Whois Data |publisher=[[Whois]].com|date=2013-10-12}}</ref> Where it has received several positive reviews from such internet guides as "The parents' pocket guide to kids & computers" by Family Computer Workshop, which gave the site 5 out of 5 stars and recommended it for readers 7–13.<ref>{{cite book| title = The Parents' Pocket Guide to Kids & Computers |authors=Family Computer Workshop Staff| publisher = Family Computer Workshop | year = 1998 | page = 166 | isbn = 0966645634}}</ref> At the time the site contained questions and answers, as well as hands-on activities, some of which required [[Netscape]] and [[Shockwave]].<ref>{{cite book | first = Elizabeth B. | last = Miller | title = The Internet Resource Directory for K–12 Teachers and Librarians | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | year = 2001 | page = 174 | isbn = 1563089130}}</ref>
The final strip was published on July 17, 2016, three days after its 25th anniversary and three months after Jok Church died.
